title: Karelian Isthmus
text:
The Karelian Isthmus (; ; ) is the approximately stretch of land, situated between the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Finland">Gulf of Finland</a> and <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> in northwestern <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, to the north of the <a href="River%20Neva">River Neva</a>. Its northwestern boundary is a line from the <a href="Bay%20of%20Vyborg">Bay of Vyborg</a> to the westernmost point of Lake Ladoga, Pekonlahti. If the Karelian Isthmus is defined as the entire territory of present-day <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> and <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a> to the north of the Neva and also a tiny part of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Karelia">Republic of Karelia</a>, the area of the isthmus is about .
The smaller part of the isthmus to the southeast of the old Russia-Finland border is considered historically as Northern <a href="Ingria">Ingria</a>, rather than part of the Karelian Isthmus itself. The rest of the isthmus was historically a part of <a href="Finnish%20Karelia">Finnish Karelia</a>. This was conquered by the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a> during the <a href="Great%20Northern%20War">Great Northern War</a> in 1712 and included within the autonomous <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Finland">Grand Duchy of Finland</a> (1809–1917) of the Russian Empire. When Finland became independent in 1917, the isthmus (except for the territory roughly corresponding to present-day <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> and some districts of Saint Petersburg) remained Finnish. Finnish Karelia was partly ceded to the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> by <a href="Finland">Finland</a> following the <a href="Winter%20War">Winter War</a> (1939–1940) and <a href="Continuation%20War">Continuation War</a> (1941–1944). In 1940–1941, during the <a href="Interim%20Peace">Interim Peace</a>, most of the ceded territories in the isthmus were included within the <a href="Karelo-Finnish%20SSR">Karelo-Finnish SSR</a>. However, since <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> the entire isthmus has been divided between the city of <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> (mostly <a href="Kurortny%20District">Kurortny District</a>), as well as <a href="Priozersky%20District">Priozersky District</a>, <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> and <a href="Vyborgsky%20District%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Vyborgsky District</a> of <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a>.
According to the <a href="Russian%20Census%20%282002%29">2002 census</a>, the population of the <a href="Kurortny%20District">Kurortny District</a> of <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> and the parts of <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a> situated on the Karelian Isthmus amounts to 539,000. Many Saint Petersburg residents also decamp to the Isthmus during their vacations. The main population centers of the Isthmus are <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a> ("Выборг"; ; ), <a href="Priozersk">Priozersk</a> ("Приозе́рск"; ; ) and <a href="Primorsk%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Primorsk</a> ("Примо́рск"; ; ).
Geography and wildlife.
The isthmus' terrain has been influenced dramatically by the <a href="Weichselian%20glaciation">Weichselian glaciation</a>. Its highest point lies on the Lembolovo Heights <a href="moraine">moraine</a> at about 205 m (670 ft). There are no mountains on the isthmus, but steep hills occur in some places.
The <a href="Vuoksi">Vuoksi</a>, the largest river, runs southeastwards from Lake <a href="Saimaa">Saimaa</a> of Finland to <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a>, dividing the isthmus into two uneven parts. <a href="Saimaa%20Canal">Saimaa Canal</a> opened in 1856 links Lake Saimaa to the <a href="Bay%20of%20Vyborg">Bay of Vyborg</a> passing through the city of <a href="Lappeenranta">Lappeenranta</a> in <a href="South%20Karelia">South Karelia</a>, Finland.
The Karelian Isthmus lies within the <a href="ecoregion">ecoregion</a> of <a href="Scandinavian%20and%20Russian%20taiga">Scandinavian and Russian taiga</a>. Geobotanically, it lies at the juncture of the Central European, Eastern European and Northern European <a href="floristic%20province">floristic province</a>s of the <a href="Circumboreal%20Region">Circumboreal Region</a> of the <a href="Holarctic%20Kingdom">Holarctic Kingdom</a>.
The isthmus is mostly covered by <a href="taiga">coniferous forests</a> formed by <a href="Scots%20pine">Scots pine</a> ("Pinus sylvestris") and <a href="Norway%20spruce">Norway spruce</a> ("Picea abies"), with numerous lakes (e.g. <a href="Lake%20Sukhodolskoye">Lake Sukhodolskoye</a> and <a href="Lake%20Glubokoye%20%28Karelian%20Isthmus%29">Lake Glubokoye</a>) as well as small grass, <a href="fen">fen</a> and "Sphagnum" <a href="raised%20bog">raised bog</a>s. Forests cover approximately 11.700 km of the isthmus, more than three-fourths of its total square. Swampy areas occupy on average 5.5 percent of the territory. In the large contiguous area along the shore of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> in <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a>, in the southeastern part of the isthmus, bogs occur much more frequently than in other parts. The same was once true of the lowland along the <a href="Neva%20River">Neva River</a>, which has been drained. The soil is predominantly <a href="podsol">podsol</a>, which contains massive boulders, especially in the north and northwest, where large <a href="granite">granite</a> rocky outcrops occur.
Pine forests (with "<a href="Pinus%20sylvestris">Pinus sylvestris</a>") are the most widespread and occupy 51% of the forested area of the Karelian Isthmus, followed by spruce forests (with "<a href="Picea%20abies">Picea abies</a>", 29%) and birch forests (with "<a href="Betula%20pendula">Betula pendula</a>" and "<a href="Betula%20pubescens">B. pubescens</a>", 16%). Stands on more fertile soils and in more favorable locations are occasionally dominated by <a href="Acer%20platanoides">Norway maple</a>, <a href="Alnus%20glutinosa">black alder</a>, <a href="Alnus%20incana">grey alder</a>, <a href="Populus%20tremula">common aspen</a>, <a href="Quercus%20robur">English oak</a>, <a href="Salix%20cinerea">grey willow</a>, <a href="Salix%20myrsinifolia">dark-leaved willow</a>, <a href="Salix%20phylicifolia">tea-leaved willow</a>, <a href="Tilia%20cordata">small-leaved lime</a> or <a href="Ulmus%20laevis">European white elm</a>. Common vegetation of various types of pine forests includes <a href="Calluna%20vulgaris">heather</a>, <a href="Empetrum%20nigrum">crowberry</a>, <a href="Juniperus%20communis">common juniper</a>, <a href="Salix%20aurita">eared willow</a>, <a href="Vaccinium%20vitis-idaea">lingonberry</a>, <a href="Equisetum%20fluviatile">water horsetail</a>, <a href="Pteridium%20aquilinum">bracken</a>, graminoids (i.e. grasses in the wider sense) "<a href="Avenella%20flexuosa">Avenella flexuosa</a>" and "<a href="Carex%20globularis">Carex globularis</a>", mosses "<a href="Pleurozium%20schreberi">Pleurozium schreberi</a>", "<a href="Sphagnum%20angustifolium">Sphagnum angustifolium</a>" and "<a href="Sphagnum%20russowii">S. russowii</a>", and lichens "<a href="Cladonia">Cladonia</a>" spp. Prominent in various spruce forests are <a href="Equisetum%20sylvaticum">wood horsetail</a>, <a href="Oxalis%20acetosella">common wood sorrel</a>, <a href="Vaccinium%20myrtillus">bilberry</a>, lingonberry, graminoids "Avenella flexuosa", "<a href="Calamagrostis%20arundinacea">Calamagrostis arundinacea</a>", "Carex globularis", and mosses "<a href="Polytrichum%20commune">Polytrichum commune</a>" and "<a href="Sphagnum%20girgensohnii">Sphagnum girgensohnii</a>". Prominent vegetation of various birch forests include <a href="Filipendula%20ulmaria">meadowsweet</a>, common wood sorrel, bilberry and graminoids "Calamagrostis arundinacea" and "<a href="Calamagrostis%20canescens">C. canescens</a>".
1184 species of wild <a href="vascular%20plants">vascular plants</a> are recorded in the isthmus. See also the <a href="List%20of%20the%20vascular%20plants%20of%20the%20Karelian%20Isthmus">List of the vascular plants of the Karelian Isthmus</a>. <a href="Red%20squirrel">Red squirrel</a>, <a href="moose">moose</a>, <a href="red%20fox">red fox</a>, <a href="mountain%20hare">mountain hare</a> and <a href="boar">boar</a> (reintroduced) are typical inhabitants of the forests.
The climate of the isthmus is <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">moderately continental</a>, with 650–800 mm (25–32 in) average precipitation per year, long snowy winters lasting from November through mid-April and occasionally reaching about -40 °C (-40 F), moderately cool summers and short frost-free period. Compared to other parts of the <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a>, the winter here is usually milder due to the moderating influence of the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Finland">Gulf of Finland</a>, but longer.
The <a href="city">city</a> of <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a> and the <a href="town">town</a> of <a href="Priozersk">Priozersk</a> are situated on the northwestern part of the isthmus.
The Karelian Isthmus is a popular place for <a href="hiking">hiking</a>, <a href="cycling">cycling</a>, <a href="skiing">skiing</a> (<a href="Korobitsyno">Korobitsyno</a> and <a href="Kavgolovo">Kavgolovo</a>), <a href="climbing">climbing</a> (near <a href="Kuznechnoye">Kuznechnoye</a>), <a href="canoeing">canoeing</a> (<a href="Losevo%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Losevo</a>), <a href="fishing">fishing</a> for consumption (of <a href="carp%20bream">carp bream</a>, <a href="northern%20pike">northern pike</a>, <a href="Rutilus">roach</a>, <a href="European%20perch">European perch</a>, <a href="ruffe">ruffe</a>, <a href="burbot">burbot</a> and others), <a href="mushroom%20hunting">mushroom hunting</a> (for <a href="Boletus%20edulis">porcini</a>, <a href="Leccinum%20aurantiacum">red-capped scaber stalk</a>, <a href="Leccinum%20scabrum">birch bolete</a>, <a href="Suillus%20variegatus">velvet bolete</a>, <a href="Suillus%20luteus">slippery Jack</a>, <a href="Cantharellus%20cibarius">golden chanterelle</a>, "<a href="Lactarius%20resimus">Lactarius resimus</a>", <a href="Lactarius%20torminosus">woolly milk-cap</a>, <a href="Lactarius%20turpis">ugly milk-cap</a>, <a href="Lactarius%20deliciosus">saffron milk-cap</a>, "<a href="Lactarius%20rufus">Lactarius rufus</a>", various <a href="Russula">Russula</a>s and others), <a href="berry%20picking">berry picking</a> (of <a href="bilberry">bilberry</a>, <a href="raspberry">raspberry</a>, <a href="woodland%20strawberry">woodland strawberry</a>, <a href="cowberry">cowberry</a>, <a href="cranberry">cranberry</a>, <a href="cloudberry">cloudberry</a>, <a href="bog%20bilberry">bog bilberry</a> and <a href="stone%20bramble">stone bramble</a>). It is a popular summer resort for <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> citizens since the late 19th century, served by trains of <a href="Finlyandsky%20Rail%20Terminal">Finlyandsky Rail Terminal</a>. The isthmus, especially the land along <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%E2%80%93Riihim%C3%A4ki%20railroad">Saint Petersburg–Vyborg</a> and <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%E2%80%93Hiitola%20railroad">Saint Petersburg–Priozersk</a> railroads, hosts numerous <a href="dacha">dacha</a>s.
A 20–35 km wide stretch of land in <a href="Vyborgsky%20District%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Vyborgsky District</a> and <a href="Republic%20of%20Karelia">Republic of Karelia</a> to the west of the <a href="Vyborg%E2%80%93Hiitola%20railway">Vyborg–Hiitola railway</a>, as well as the islands and shores of the Gulf of Vyborg, belongs to the strictly guarded <a href="Border%20Security%20Zone%20of%20Russia">zone of the border control</a>, reaching the shore of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> at Hiitola. In 1993–2006 the zone was formally 5 km wide, although in fact it has always been much wider. Visiting it is forbidden without a permit issued by the <a href="FSB%20%28Russia%29">FSB</a> (by <a href="KGB">KGB</a> during the time of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>).
Geological history.
Geologically the Karelian Isthmus lies on the southern edge of the <a href="Baltic%20Shield">Baltic Shield</a>'s crystalline bedrock. During the final part of the last <a href="Weichselian%20glaciation">Weichselian glaciation</a>, deglaciation in the central parts of the Isthmus started as early as 14000 <a href="Before%20Present">BP</a>, when it formed the bottom of a large lake dammed by the surrounding <a href="ice%20sheet">ice sheet</a>. During further deglaciation, at the time of the <a href="Baltic%20Ice%20Lake">Baltic Ice Lake</a>, an early high water stage of the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, when the ice sheet retreated to <a href="Salpausselk%C3%A4">Salpausselkä</a>, the upland area of the Isthmus remained a large island and many upland lakes emerged.
Prior to 12650 BP, the land was characterized by harsh <a href="Arctic">Arctic conditions</a> with <a href="permafrost">permafrost</a> and <a href="Arctic%20vegetation">sparse vegetation</a>. <a href="Steppe-tundra">Steppe-tundra</a> complexes developed after this point. Around 11000 BP climate began to warm and became humid, first pine and birch forests were established.
Around 9000 BP <a href="Ancylus%20Lake">Ancylus Lake</a>, another stage of the Baltic Sea, retreated, and many lowland lakes were also isolated in depressions formed earlier by <a href="glaciation">glacial exaration</a> and fluvioglacial activity. <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> was separated from the sea as well. Due to land uplift, around 5000 BP the <a href="River%20Vuoksi">River Vuoksi</a> started emptying into Lake Ladoga as a new outlet of <a href="Lake%20Saimaa">Lake Saimaa</a>. Lake Ladoga <a href="transgression%20%28geology%29">transgressed</a>, flooding lowland lakes and the Vuoksi, and became connected with the sea at <a href="Heinjoki">Heinjoki</a> (now Veshchevo), to the east of present-day <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a>. Around 3100–2400 BP the <a href="Neva%20River">Neva River</a> emerged, draining <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> into the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. Ladoga level gradually sank from 15–18 m to its modern position of 4–5 m above sea-level, and lowland lakes were isolated again. However, the Vuoksi still had a significant direct outflow connection to the <a href="Bay%20of%20Vyborg">Bay of Vyborg</a>, possibly as late as in the 12th century AD. The connection disappeared due to ongoing land uplift in the 2nd millennium AD.
In 1818 a canal, which was dug to drain spring flood waters from <a href="Lake%20Suvanto">Lake Suvanto</a> (now Lake Sukhodolskoye, a 40-km long narrow lake in the eastern part of the Isthmus) into <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a>, unexpectedly eroded and turned into the <a href="Taipaleenjoki">Taipaleenjoki</a> (now Burnaya River). The Taipaleenjoki started draining Suvanto and decreased its level by 7 m. Originally waters of Lake Suvanto flowed into the Vuoksi River through a waterway at <a href="Losevo%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Kiviniemi</a> (now Losevo), but as a result of the change, the waterway dried out. In 1857 the canal was dug there, but the stream reversed direction, revealed <a href="rapids">rapids</a> and rendered navigation at Kiviniemi impossible. Since 1857 Suvanto and the Taipaleenjoki have constituted the southern armlet of the Vuoksi River, which has decreased the level of the original northern armlet emptying into Ladoga near <a href="Kexholm">Kexholm</a> (now Priozersk) by 4 m, isolating it as a separate river basin.
Administrative territorial division.
The Karelian Isthmus is located in two regions of the <a href="Russian%20Federation">Russian Federation</a>, <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> and the <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a>. Saint Petersburg is represented by seven districts, the Leningrad Oblast by three.
History.
Archaeology.
Apart from the old towns of <a href="Vyborg%20Castle">Vyborg</a> and <a href="Korela%20Fortress">Priozersk</a>, and churches on the <a href="Konevets">Konevets</a> island of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a>, since the late 19th century a number of other archaeological sites have been discovered on the isthmus. Numerous archaeological remnants of the <a href="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a>, <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>, <a href="Copper%20Age">Copper Age</a> and <a href="Bronze%20Age">Bronze Age</a> occur all over the isthmus. The eastern part of the Karelian Isthmus hosts a number of medieval remnants. There are many grave pits of <a href="Karelian%20people">Karelians</a> of the 10th–15th centuries with metal and ceramic artifacts along the northern armlet of the Vuoksi, near <a href="Lake%20Sukhodolskoye">Lake Sukhodolskoye</a> and in a few other places in <a href="Priozersky%20District">Priozersky District</a>. On the southern shore of Lake Sukhodolskoye small medieval <a href="burial%20mounds">burial mounds</a> are abundant as well. A lot of large cult stones have been found along these bodies of water, as well as agglomerations of <a href="cairn">cairn</a>s. Remnants of several rural settlements were also discovered there as well as on the shore of Lake Ladoga. Remnants of the Tiuri (<a href="Tiversk">Tiversk</a>) town (10th–15th centuries) were excavated on a former island in the northern Vuoksi armlet near the Tiuri village (now Vasilyevo). A few treasures of silver adornments and medieval Arabian and Western European coins have also been found, as the isthmus laid on the <a href="Volga%20trade%20route">Volga trade route</a> (at that time, the <a href="Vuoksi%20River">Vuoksi River</a> had a distributary emptying into the <a href="Bay%20of%20Vyborg">Bay of Vyborg</a>).
Prehistory and Medieval.
Ancestors of <a href="Baltic%20Finns">Baltic Finns</a> wandered to the Karelian Isthmus possibly around 8500BC.
In the 11th century, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> and <a href="Novgorod%20Republic">Novgorod Republic</a> started to compete tax holding rights. The <a href="Treaty%20of%20N%C3%B6teborg">Treaty of Nöteborg</a> of 1323 established a border between them along the rivers now known as the <a href="Sestra%20River%20%28Leningrad%20Oblast%29">Sestra</a> and the <a href="Volchya%20River%20%28Vuoksi%20tributary%29">Volchya</a>.
17th–20th centuries.
During 17th century Sweden gained the whole isthmus and also <a href="Ingria">Ingria</a>. In this time many Karelians escaped to <a href="Tver%20Karelia">Tver's Karelia</a>.
From 1721–1812 the isthmus belonged to the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>, won in the <a href="Great%20Northern%20War">Great Northern War</a> that started with the Russian conquest of Ingria where the new imperial <a href="Capital%20%28political%29">capital</a>, Saint Petersburg, was founded (1703) in the southern end of the isthmus, in place of old Swedish town <a href="Nyenskans">Nyenskans</a>. Then in 1812, the northwestern half was transferred, as a part of <a href="Old%20Finland">Old Finland</a>, to the autonomous <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Finland">Grand Duchy of Finland</a>, created in 1809 and in a <a href="personal%20union">personal union</a> with Russia.
Due to its size, favorable climate, rich fishing waters and proximity to <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, the capital of the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>, the Karelian Isthmus became the wealthiest part of Finland once the <a href="industrial%20revolution">industrial revolution</a> had gained momentum in the 19th century. The railroads <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%E2%80%93Riihim%C3%A4ki%20railroad">Saint Petersburg–Vyborg–Riihimäki</a> (1870), <a href="Vyborg%E2%80%93Joensuu%20railroad">Vyborg–Hiitola–Sortavala</a> (1893), <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%E2%80%93Hiitola%20railroad">Saint Petersburg–Kexholm–Hiitola</a> (1917) crossed the isthmus, contributing to its economic development. By the end of the 19th century the nearby areas along the Saint Petersburg–Vyborg section had become popular place of summer resort for wealthy Saint Petersburgers.
When Finland declared its independence in 1917, the isthmus (except for the territory roughly corresponding to present-day <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> and some districts of Saint Petersburg) remained Finnish, part of the <a href="Viipuri%20province">Viipuri province</a> with its center in <a href="Vyborg">Viipuri</a>, the fourth largest Finnish city. A considerable part of the remaining area populated by <a href="Ingrian%20Finns">Ingrian Finns</a> seceded from <a href="Russian%20Soviet%20Federative%20Socialist%20Republic">Bolshevist Russia</a> as the Finland-backed <a href="Republic%20of%20North%20Ingria">Republic of North Ingria</a>, but was reintegrated with Russia in the end of 1920 according to the conditions of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Tartu%20%28Russian%E2%80%93Finnish%29">Treaty of Tartu</a>. In 1928–1939 parts of the isthmus which belonged to Russia constituted the Kuivaisi National District with its center in <a href="Toksova">Toksova</a>, with <a href="Finnish%20language">Finnish</a> as the official language, according to the policy of <a href="national%20delimitation%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">national delimitation in the Soviet Union</a>. However, in 1936 the entire Finnish population of the parishes of <a href="Valkeasaari">Valkeasaari</a>, <a href="Lembolovo">Lempaala</a>, <a href="Vuole">Vuole</a> and <a href="Miikkulainen">Miikkulainen</a> along the Finnish border was <a href="population%20transfer%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">deported</a> by the Soviet government.
World War II.
A number of defensive lines crossed the isthmus during the Soviet-Finnish hostilities in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, such as <a href="Mannerheim%20Line">Mannerheim Line</a>, <a href="VKT-line">VKT-line</a>, <a href="VT-line">VT-line</a>, Main line (Finnish) and <a href="KaUR">KaUR</a> (Soviet), and fronts moved back and forth over it.
In November 1939, the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> staged the <a href="Shelling%20of%20Mainila">Shelling of Mainila</a> and invaded Finland in what became known as the <a href="Winter%20War">Winter War</a>, which took a disproportionally heavy death toll on the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a>. Only in February 1940 did the Soviet forces manage to penetrate the <a href="Mannerheim%20Line">Mannerheim Line</a> across the isthmus, the strength of which is often exaggerated. Finland ceded the Karelian Isthmus and <a href="Ladoga%20Karelia">Ladoga Karelia</a> to the Soviet Union in the <a href="Moscow%20Peace%20Treaty%20%281940%29">Peace of Moscow</a> of 12 March. According to the protocol appended to the Moscow Peace Treaty, the fighting was ended at noon (Leningrad time) on 13 March and by 26 March the Finnish troops had been completely withdrawn. The entire Karelian population of the ceded areas of about 422 thousand people was evacuated to other parts of <a href="Finland">Finland</a> (see <a href="Evacuation%20of%20Finnish%20Karelia">Evacuation of Finnish Karelia</a>). On 31 March most of the ceded territories were incorporated into <a href="Karelo-Finnish%20SSR">Karelo-Finnish SSR</a> by a decision of the <a href="Supreme%20Council%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Supreme Council of the Soviet Union</a> (in the Karelian Isthmus the districts of <a href="J%C3%A4%C3%A4ski">Jääski</a>, <a href="Kexholm">Kexholm</a> and <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a>). The districts of <a href="Pobeda%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Kanneljärvi</a>, <a href="Primorsk%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Koivisto</a> and <a href="Rautu">Rautu</a> as well as the town of <a href="Terijoki">Terijoki</a> were, however, included into <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a>.
In 1941, during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Germany invaded the Soviet Union in <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>. Few days later <a href="Continuation%20War">Continuation War</a> as it is known in Finland (it is considered to be a front of the <a href="Great%20Patriotic%20War">Great Patriotic War</a> in the Soviet Union and Russia) started. Finland initially regained the lost territory, reaching the Russian side of the border of 1939 and seen by the Russians as indirectly contributing to the <a href="Siege%20of%20Leningrad">Siege of Leningrad</a> (see <a href="Finnish%20reconquest%20of%20the%20Karelian%20Isthmus%20%281941%29">Finnish reconquest of the Karelian Isthmus (1941)</a>). Some 260,000 Karelian evacuees returned home.
On 9 June 1944, strong Soviet forces opened the <a href="Vyborg%20Offensive">Vyborg Offensive</a> and pushed the front from the pre-1939 border to Vyborg in ten days. The returned Karelians were <a href="Evacuation%20of%20Finnish%20Karelia">evacuated</a> to <a href="Finland">Finland</a> again. In the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tali-Ihantala">Battle of Tali-Ihantala</a>, 25 June–9 July, the Finns concentrated their military strength and brought the offensive to a halt at the <a href="River%20Vuoksi">River Vuoksi</a>, in the northwesternmost part of the isthmus, at the closest point only 40 kilometres from the border of 1940. The <a href="Moscow%20Armistice">Moscow Armistice</a> ending the war was signed on 19 September 1944. The entire isthmus became Soviet, although most of it has never been captured by the Soviets in battles. This time the ceded territories of the Karelian Isthmus (including the districts of <a href="J%C3%A4%C3%A4ski">Jääski</a>, <a href="Kexholm">Kexholm</a> and <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a>) were incorporated into <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a> (unlike Ladoga Karelia, which remained within the Karelo-Finnish SSR). The border of the <a href="Moscow%20Peace%20Treaty%20%281940%29">Moscow Peace Treaty (1940)</a> was recognized by Finland again in the <a href="Paris%20Peace%20Treaties%2C%201947">Peace of Paris</a>, 1947. 
After the war.
As a result of the war, the population of the Karelian Isthmus has been almost completely replaced. After the war the isthmus was included into the <a href="Leningrad%20Oblast">Leningrad Oblast</a> and people from other parts of the Soviet Union, mostly Russian, were settled here. The vast majority of the old Finnish <a href="wikt%3Atoponym">toponyms</a> in the conquered territories were renamed to invented Russian ones by the government around 1948. The Finnish toponyms of the territories included within Karelo-Finnish SSR and of the southern part of the isthmus (albeit assimilated) mostly remained. A lot of <a href="Young%20Pioneer%20camp">youth summer camps</a> were built all over the isthmus during the time of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. Some of them still exist.
Transport.
The western part of the Karelian Isthmus is an important <a href="transport%20corridor">transport corridor</a> linking <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> and <a href="European%20Russia">Central Russia</a>. <a href="Primorsk%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Primorsk</a>, terminus of the <a href="Baltic%20Pipeline%20System">Baltic Pipeline System</a>, which has recently become one of the most efficient Russian <a href="sea%20port">sea port</a>s, is also located here.
The only <a href="motorway">motorway</a> on the isthmus is the recently completed <a href="European%20route%20E18">E18 "Scandinavia"</a> (M10) going from <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a> through <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a> and <a href="Vaalimaa">Vaalimaa</a>.
<a href="Saimaa%20Canal">Saimaa Canal</a> (opened in 1856) is an important link connecting inland waterways of <a href="Finland">Finland</a> with the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Finland">Gulf of Finland</a>.
The Karelian Isthmus is served by a number of railways; the trains arrive from <a href="Finlyandsky%20Rail%20Terminal">Finlyandsky Rail Terminal</a> and <a href="Ladozhsky%20Rail%20Terminal">Ladozhsky Rail Terminal</a> of <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>:
Also on the Karelian isthmus are all lines of the St. <a href="Petersburg%20metro">Petersburg metro</a>.
Industry.
The <a href="pulp-and-paper">pulp-and-paper</a>, <a href="logging">timber</a> and <a href="woodworking">woodworking</a> industries ("JSC Svetogorsk", pulp and paper mill in <a href="Svetogorsk">Svetogorsk</a>, "Vyborgsky Pulp and Paper Mill" in <a href="Vyborg">Vyborg</a>, "Priozersky Furniture and Woodworking Industrial Complex" and "Priozersky Woodworking Factory" in <a href="Priozersk">Priozersk</a>, as well as other smaller enterprises all over the isthmus) are well developed in <a href="Vyborgsky%20District">Vyborgsky</a> and <a href="Priozersky%20District">Priozersky</a> Districts. The <a href="pulp%20and%20paper%20industry">pulp and paper industry</a>, however, affects the environment adversely. The predecessor of the Priozersk facilities, "Priozersky Pulp and Paper Mill", a major <a href="water%20pollution">polluter</a> of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> constructed in 1931, was closed down in 1986. Northern and western parts of the isthmus are also an important reserve of <a href="granite">granite</a> (quarries in <a href="Kuznechnoye">Kuznechnoye</a>, as well as a number of others along the <a href="Vyborg-Hiitola%20railroad">Vyborg-Hiitola railroad</a>).
"Vyborg Shipyard" is one of the largest <a href="shipbuilding%20companies">shipbuilding companies</a> in <a href="Northwestern%20Russia">Northwestern Russia</a>. "Roskar Battery Farm" in <a href="Pervomayskoye%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Pervomayskoye</a> is a leading producer of <a href="chicken%20%28food%29">chicken</a> and <a href="egg%20%28food%29">eggs</a>.
In <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> state-owned "Morozov Plant" is located, which is an important producer of <a href="paint">paint</a>s, <a href="adhesive">adhesive</a>s, <a href="abrasive">abrasive</a>s and other substances. In Kuzmolovsky, <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a>, near the station Kapitolovo of the <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%E2%80%93Hiitola%20railroad">Saint Petersburg–Hiitola railroad</a>, a facility of the Saint Petersburg nuclear enterprise "Izotop" is located, which specializes in transportation of <a href="nuclear%20materials">nuclear materials</a> and <a href="radioactive%20waste">radioactive waste</a>. <a href="Bogs">Bogs</a> of <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> along the shores of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> and the <a href="Neva%20River">Neva River</a> were major sources of <a href="peat">peat</a> for fuel. Now it is extracted in smaller quantities, mostly for agricultural purposes. The district is also an important supplier of <a href="sand">sand</a>. A plant of <a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford Motor Company</a> producing <a href="Ford%20Focus%20%28International%29">Ford Focus</a> cars was opened in <a href="Vsevolozhsk">Vsevolozhsk</a> in 2002.
Military.
The Karelian Isthmus is included within <a href="Leningrad%20Military%20District">Leningrad Military District</a> of the <a href="Armed%20Forces%20of%20the%20Russian%20Federation">Armed Forces of the Russian Federation</a>. The isthmus hosts airfields in <a href="Levashovo%20%28air%20base%29">Levashovo</a>, <a href="Pribylovo">Pribylovo</a> and <a href="Gromovo">Gromovo</a>. Other airfields in <a href="Veshchevo">Veshchevo</a> and <a href="Kasimovo">Kasimovo</a> (Vartemyagi) have been abandoned. In the northern part of <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a>, to the south of the old Finnish border, <a href="Karelian%20Fortified%20Region">Karelian Fortified Region</a> (KaUR) is located, which was reconstructed as late as in the 1960s, but now seems to be abandoned as well. There is "Bobochinsky tank range" (195.975 km², founded in 1913) between <a href="Kamenka%2C%20Vyborgsky%20District%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Kamenka</a> and <a href="Kirillovsky%20District">Kirillovskoye</a> and a number of military facilities in <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a> in the lowlands between <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> and <a href="Saint%20Petersburg-Hiitola%20railroad">Saint Petersburg-Hiitola railroad</a>, including "Rzhevsky artillery range" (founded in 1879), a huge area, , encircled by the <a href="Road%20of%20Life">Road of Life</a>, the roads <a href="Rzhevka">Rzhevka</a> – <a href="Novoye%20Devyatkino">Novoye Devyatkino</a> and Novoye Devyatkino – <a href="Matoksa">Matoksa</a> and the coast of <a href="Lake%20Ladoga">Lake Ladoga</a> (available to visitors since 2003). In 2006 a <a href="Voronezh%20radar">Voronezh</a> <a href="early%20warning%20radar">early warning radar</a> was built in <a href="Lekhtusi%20Radar%20Station">Lekhtusi</a>, <a href="Vsevolozhsky%20District">Vsevolozhsky District</a>. The port of <a href="Vysotsk">Vysotsk</a> is a base of the <a href="Baltic%20Fleet">Baltic Fleet</a>. 138th Guards Motor Rifle Brigade is located in <a href="Kamenka%2C%20Vyborgsky%20District%2C%20Leningrad%20Oblast">Kamenka</a>, and in the 56th District Training Centre in <a href="Sertolovo">Sertolovo</a>.
Population.
The population of the Karelian isthmus today is slightly less than 3.1 million inhabitants. Of these, about 2.4 million live in St. Petersburg and a little less than 700 thousand in the Leningrad region. The population is growing solely due to migration, as the mortality rate is much higher than the birth rate, but the migration attractiveness of St. Petersburg and the surrounding areas of the Leningrad region is very high. Thus, about 40% of the population of St. Petersburg and about 30% of the population of the Leningrad region live on the Karelian isthmus. There is strong growth in population in all the districts of the Karelian isthmus in addition to the Vyborg district and Priozersk district .
